meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>treasure</kanji> <kanji>stone</kanji> is a very valuable stone. What kind of stones are considered treasures? How about a <vocabulary>jewel</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>gem</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please give me a red tie.
examples.ja: 赤いネクタイを下さい。

examples.en: Red nail polish is popular right now.
examples.ja: 今、赤いマニキュアが人気ですよ。

examples.en: This tomato just turned red today.
examples.ja: このトマト、今日赤くなったばかりなんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>red</kanji>? Why, it's <vocabulary>red</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: That white dog is our pet.
examples.ja: その白い犬はうちのペットです。

examples.en: White asparagus is quite tasty.
examples.ja: 白いアスパラガスは中々おいしいですよ。

examples.en: The white rabbit had red eyes.
examples.ja: 白いウサギは赤い目をしていました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>white</kanji>? <vocabulary>White</vocabulary>, of course!
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the vocab 白 you learned, so you already know the reading. Go you!

examples.en: This book is about a hundred pages.
examples.ja: この本は、およそ百ページです。

examples.en: When I was little, juice was one hundred yen.
examples.ja: 小さいころ、ジュースは一つ百円でした。

examples.en: A hundred cosplay masters gathered at the event.
examples.ja: イベントには百人のコスプレ名人があつまりました。

meaning_mnemonic: When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's <vocabulary>one hundred</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!

examples.en: There is a test on the twentieth.
examples.ja: 二十日にテストがあります。

examples.en: It will be 2019 in twenty days.
examples.ja: あと二十日で２０１９年です。

examples.en: I will get a bonus on the 20th.
examples.ja: 二十日にボーナスが出ます。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Two</kanji> times <kanji>ten</kanji> <kanji>days</kanji> is <vocabulary>twenty days</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Words that count days use an exceptional reading. The readings for 二十 are exceptions, and 日 takes the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help with that:

If you make one hat for <vocabulary>twenty days</vocabulary> you'll have enough <reading>hats</reading> (はつ) to fill up your <reading>car</reading> (か) completely! That's a lot of days and a lot of hats.

examples.en: Please give me the whole thing, not just half.
examples.ja: 半分じゃなくて丸ごと一つ下さい。

examples.en: I ate a whole pint ice cream all by myself.
examples.ja: パイントのアイスを丸ごと一人でたべた。

examples.en: I got a whole case of mangoes.
examples.ja: マンゴーをケース丸ごともらった。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you go to (ごと) a <kanji>circle</kanji>, you need to go to it <vocabulary>in its entirety</vocabulary>. That means you have to circle around the <vocabulary>whole</vocabulary> thing. Otherwise, it isn't even a circle. It's like a line or a squiggle or something.

You often hear this word when talking about food – like when biting into a whole apple or accidentally swallowing a grape without chewing. But it's not just for food: you can also use it to talk about memorizing a whole book from beginning to end, for example.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading, so you should be able to read this too!

examples.en: Should we go out somewhere on May 3rd?
examples.ja: 五月三日はどこかに出かける？

examples.en: I go to the mountains on my days off.
examples.ja: 休みの日は山へ出かける。

examples.en: Tanaka-san left for their honeymoon in Hawaii.
examples.ja: 田中さんは、ハワイのハネムーンに出かけましたよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>exit</kanji> but you do it with かける added to it. Just think of that かける as you are exiting while being "cocky" about it. You do this when you want <vocabulary>to go out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to leave</vocabulary>. You go out in a cocky way!

This word can only be used for a person going out. You can't say a train 出かける'd.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 出る, so if you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!

examples.en: I developed an allergy because of the polluted atmosphere.
examples.ja: きたない大気のせいでアレルギーになりました。

examples.en: There is almost no atmosphere on the moon.
examples.ja: 月には、ほとんど大気がないんだって。

examples.en: The rocket finally left the atmosphere.
examples.ja: ついにロケットが大気から出た。

meaning_mnemonic: If there is a <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> it's going to fill up the <vocabulary>atmosphere</vocabulary>! Think about big energies you feel in the atmosphere: thunderstorms, tornadoes, the aurora borealis. Just remember, this is the atmosphere in the sky, not the atmosphere in a fancy restaurant.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Imagine an <vocabulary>atmosphere</vocabulary> consisting entirely of <reading>tie</reading>s and <reading>key</reading>s (たいき), floating around. The ties are getting tangled together, and the keys keep bashing you on the head. Bring back the normal atmosphere, this one's horrible.

examples.en: The queen often says, "you're right."
examples.ja: 女王は、よく「そうね」と口にする。

examples.en: Don't say that name.
examples.ja: その名は口にするな。

examples.en: I got drunk off a little whisky.
examples.ja: ウィスキーを口にしたら、よっぱらってしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've already learned that 口 means "mouth" and here it's followed by the particle に, which pinpoints a location. The verb する means "to do" so you're doing something to your mouth! Logically enough, this expression is used to describe lots of actions that you do with your mouth. It's often used to mean <vocabulary>to mention</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to say</vocabulary>, but with an added descriptive nuance that you've said something accidentally or unexpectedly, maybe something you shouldn't have said! 🙊

It can also mean other things done with the mouth, like <vocabulary>to eat</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to drink</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: In this expression, 口 is a standalone vocabulary word, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.

examples.en: Canada is located in North America.
examples.ja: カナダは北アメリカにあります。

examples.en: Is this river in North America?
examples.ja: これって北アメリカの川ですか？

examples.en: I went camping in the mountains of North America.
examples.ja: 北アメリカの山でキャンプをしました。

meaning_mnemonic:
You already encountered アメリカ in the previous level, so you should know that it means "America." Put <kanji>north</kanji> in front of this and you get <vocabulary>North America</vocabulary>, just like in English!

Note that 北アメリカ refers to the continent of North America, as opposed to the northern part of the USA. アメリカ on its own usually means the USA, but when it has "north" or "south" in front of it like this, it's always referring to the continents.
reading_mnemonic: You might be tempted to read this using the on'yomi readings, but this actually uses kun'yomi. You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should have no problems reading this!

examples.en: Which one of these ties shall I give as a gift?
examples.ja: プレゼントのネクタイ、どれにする？

examples.en: Can you tell which ones are tasty onions?
examples.ja: どれがおいしい玉ねぎか、分かる？

examples.en: Hmm, which one should I cut first?
examples.ja: えっと、どれから切ればいい？

meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>Do re</reading> (どれ) mi fa sol la ti... <vocabulary>which one</vocabulary> of these notes are you going to start singing from?

The question word どれ is used to ask <vocabulary>which one</vocabulary> out of three or more choices.

examples.en: I'm going to speak on TV now.
examples.ja: 今から、テレビでしゃべるんだ。

examples.en: What, you're going on TV?
examples.ja: えっ、テレビに出るの？

examples.en: I'll turn on the TV immediately!
examples.ja: すぐにテレビをつけるよ！

meaning_mnemonic:
テレビ comes from the English word <vocabulary>television</vocabulary>. It’s been shortened, which is really common with loanwords in Japanese. The "vi" sound becomes ビ, too.

テレビ is sometimes written as "TV", but even then it’s usually pronounced テレビ.

examples.en: Yep, let's do that!
examples.ja: うん、そうしよう！

examples.en: Yeah, sorry, that's wrong.
examples.ja: うん、ごめん、ちがう。

examples.en: Yep, it's yummy!
examples.ja: うん、おいしい！

meaning_mnemonic:
Wanna play <reading>Un</reading>o (うん)? <vocabulary>Yep</vocabulary>! 'Course I do. I always wanna play Uno.

うん is a casual way to say <vocabulary>yes</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>yeah</vocabulary>, so you’d generally use it with friends and family, and in other informal situations.

examples.en: "Mr. Chandler." "Yes!"
examples.ja: 「チャンドラーさん」「はい！」

examples.en: Yes, thank you very much.
examples.ja: はい、ありがとうございます。

examples.en: Yes, understood.
examples.ja: はい、分かりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Want me to write a <reading>hai</reading>ku (はい)? <vocabulary>Yes</vocabulary>, of course!

はい is a formal word for "yes". You can use it to let someone know they’re right, or simply that you’re listening, as well as to respond if someone says your name.

examples.en: If it's that notebook you mean, it's on my desk.
examples.ja: そのノートなら、デスクの上だよ。

examples.en: Did you take good notes on the lesson?
examples.ja: レッスン、ちゃんとノートにまとめた？

examples.en: I need an A4 size notebook, you know.
examples.ja: A4サイズのノートがいるんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
ノート is a shortened form of <vocabulary>notebook</vocabulary>, with an extra "o" on the end since you can’t end a word with "t" in Japanese.

You can also use this to mean <vocabulary>notes</vocabulary>, in the context of taking down notes in a class.

examples.en: Goodbye Sensei.
examples.ja: 先生、さようなら。

examples.en: Goodbye January. Hello February.
examples.ja: さようなら、一月。こんにちは、二月。

examples.en: So long, and thanks for all the fish.
examples.ja: さようなら、今までサカナをありがとう。

meaning_mnemonic:
I <reading>saw your Nara</reading> (さようなら), but I then had to say <vocabulary>goodbye</vocabulary>. It was just a short trip, but at least I saw your Nara.

さようなら is a formal way to say goodbye, so a good word to use with colleagues and teachers.

A quick tip before I say goodbye: さようなら often drops its middle う, becoming さよなら.

examples.en: Oh, good evening.
examples.ja: あ、こんばんは。

examples.en: Good evening, everyone.
examples.ja: みなさん、こんばんは。

examples.en: Good evening. Nice work today!
examples.ja: こんばんは〜、おつかれさまです！

meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>Con ban, wah!</reading> (こんばんは) cries your friend, just as you say <vocabulary>good evening</vocabulary>. There's a report on the evening news about a con ban (yes, that's a ban on conning people). Wah! Exciting stuff.

You can use こんばんは as a greeting from around 5pm or 6pm, in both formal and informal situations.　Watch out for that は on the end, which is pronounced わ here too.
